   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Requiring multiple pressors - vasopressin and phenylephrine.
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential. The patient does not meet ARDS criteria although
   difficult to exclude.  Continues on sedation with propofol, requiring
   phenylephrine.  Failed 3 pressure support trials.  Increased O2
   requirment this AM.  Respiratory failure may be partially secondary to
   pneumonia.  Has known Klebsiella pneumonia.
   - maintain tidal volume in ARDS net goals
   - will attempt pressure support trial to see if patient is able to
   maintain ventilation on her own.
   - wean as tolerated
   - f/u sputum cultures
   - CT chest (while doing CT abdomen for pancreatitis / acalculus
   cholecystitis eval)
   # Distributive shock:
   Patient is now demonstrating sepsis physiology with decent cardiac
   output but low SVR, likely septic, but consider that it may be
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Consider also acalculus cholecystitis.
   Likely source is pneumonia as sputum has grown out klebsiella x3,
   pan-sensitive, but concerning because this bacterium grew while patient
   on cefepime (underdosed).  Abscess unlikely because of negative CT on
   [**1-4**]. Pt continues to have increasing leukocytosis.  C diff negative.
   Central line replaced on [**2142-1-7**].  Pan-cultured again yesterday.  ID
   consulted.  Abx switched from meropenum/cipro/vanc to vanc/zosyn.
   Increased pressor requirement overnight and stable WBC.  Re-scan shows
   no evidence of an abscess, however there is potential early pseudocyst
   formation in the pancreas.
   -          f/u sputum culture w new sensitivities
   -          continue vasopressin, phenylephrine as needed to maintain
   pressures.
   .
   # Pancreatitis:
   Patient grimaced in pain when abdomen pressed.  Lipase 220. Started
   fentanyl boluses for comfort.  Triglyceride level normal.  Abdominal
   ultrasound shows no evidence of duct dilation or cholecyctitis.
   Pancreatic enzymes remain even.
   -          continue fentanyl boluses as needed and NPO (no tube feeds)
   except meds
   -          will consider advancing NG tube past ligament of treitz to
   restart tube feeds.
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine has now gone up to 1.5 from
   1.0 on admission.  This is concerning as along with her pancreatitis,
   she may now be in MODS. Still currently making urine at approximately
   40cc an hour.
   -          will transfuse with 1 unit blood to improve kidney
   perfusion.
   -          Check urine lytes.
   .
   #. Cardiogenic shock , s/p STEMI:
   The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest. S/p removal of
   ECMO and tendemheart. Now relatively resolved after stunned myocardium
   had chance to recover s/p STEMI.
   - continue vasopressin and phenylephrine
   - continue heparin gtt for potential LV thrombus.
   - PCI vs CABG when stable ; might need MVR if got CABG
   - low dose metoprolol 12.5mg tid
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem heart has
   been removed.  New crit drop today to 23.8, given ongoing sepsis this
   is concerning for potential DIC.
   - check haptoglobin, fibrinogen levels.
   - will transfuse 1 unit PRBCs
   #. Neurologic status:
   CT scan showed no evidence of acute infarction, although MRI is
   superior in detecting this.  Neurology has stated that it is not
   possible to prognosticate currently.  She is now responding much more
   vigorously to voice, turning her head and opening eyes, tracking.
   However still not able to move extremities.  CT head shows no evidence
   of stroke.
   - appreciate neurology input
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   - family will try to use Tagalog phrases in case she lost her second
   language
   - consider LP in the future, though meningitis unlikely
   # Nutrition:  NPO for pancreatitis
   -          will consider advancing NG tube to allow continued feeding.
   -          Consider TPN.
   # Atrial fibrillation: - has not been in afib recently
   - will discontinue given potential for pancreatic toxicity.
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding
   - ENT will follow if needed
   # Hyperglycemia
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
   -          ISS
   -          Consider long acting insulin.
    # Goals of care
 patient now DNR (already intubated)

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cardiogenic shock, sepsis, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She had a history of syncope episode and chest pain, and was found to have 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis on cardiac catheterization. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and was intubated for respiratory distress. She has been receiving vasopressors and mechanical ventilation to support her hemodynamics and respiratory status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving vasopressin and phenylephrine to maintain her blood pressure.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 280 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of cardiogenic shock, but her cardiac output has improved since the removal of the tandem heart and ECMO.
* Neurological: The patient is responding to voice and is able to track objects, but is not able to move her extremities.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL.
* Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis with a lipase level of 220 IU/L and no evidence of duct dilation or cholecystitis on abdominal ultrasound.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 23.8 g/dL and a hematocrit of 25.6%.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to her pneumonia and pancreatitis.
* ARDS: The patient's ARDS may worsen if she is not able to wean off mechanical ventilation.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen if she is not able to receive adequate nutrition and hydration.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if she is not able to receive adequate fluid management and vasopressor support.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she is not able to receive adequate blood transfusions.
* Neurological: The patient's neurological status may worsen if she is not able to receive adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's cardiovascular status may worsen if she is not able to receive adequate vasopressor support.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust vasopressor support as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust mechanical ventilation as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust oxygenation and ventilation as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust fluid management and vasopressor support as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust blood transfusions as needed.
* Consider advancing the patient's NG tube to allow for continued feeding.
* Consider starting TPN if the patient is unable to receive adequate nutrition through the NG tube.
* Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and adjust nutrition and hydration as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's creatinine level and adjust fluid management and vasopressor support as needed.
* Consider performing a CT scan of the head to rule out intracranial bleed or stroke.
* Consider performing a MRI of the brain to rule out intracranial bleed or stroke.
* Consider performing a LP to rule out meningitis.
* Consider starting long-acting insulin to control the patient's hyperglycemia.
* Consider discontinuing the patient's heparin infusion if her creatinine level improves.
* Consider discontinuing the patient's vasopressin and phenylephrine if her blood pressure improves.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% left main disease and 99% left anterior descending stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and is currently receiving dopamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 280 mL and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. Her oxygen requirement has increased, and she has failed three pressure support trials.
* Distributive shock: She is demonstrating sepsis physiology with a low systemic vascular resistance, likely secondary to pneumonia. Her white blood cell count is increasing, and she has a central line infection.
* Pancreatitis: She has a lipase level of 220 and is experiencing abdominal pain. Her pancreatic enzymes are even, and her abdominal ultrasound shows no evidence of duct dilation or cholecystitis.
* Acute kidney injury: Her creatinine level has increased to 1.5 from 1.0 on admission, and she is making urine at a rate of 40 cc/hour.
* Cardiogenic shock: She had a cardiogenic shock episode after PEA arrest, but it has resolved after removal of the ECMO and tandem heart.
* Anemia: Her hemoglobin level has decreased to 23.8, and she is receiving a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells.
* Neurologic status: She is responding to voice and is able to turn her head and open her eyes, but she is still not able to move her extremities.
* Nutrition: She is currently NPO due to pancreatitis, but her NG tube may be advanced to allow for continued feeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if her oxygen requirement continues to increase, and she may require more aggressive respiratory support.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis physiology may worsen if her central line infection is not treated promptly, and she may require more aggressive antimicrobial therapy.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen if her pancreatic enzymes continue to be elevated, and she may require more aggressive treatment with antibiotics and/or pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if her creatinine level continues to increase, and she may require more aggressive treatment with dialysis.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock episode may recur if her cardiomyopathy is not treated promptly, and she may require more aggressive treatment with inotropes and/or vasopressors.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if her hemoglobin level continues to decrease, and she may require more aggressive transfusion therapy.
* Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status may worsen if her brain injury is not treated promptly, and she may require more aggressive treatment with anticonvulsants and/or sedatives.
* Nutrition: The patient's nutrition may worsen if her NG tube is not advanced to allow for continued feeding, and she may require more aggressive nutrition support with parenteral nutrition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope, chest pain, and cardiac catheterization showing 95% left main coronary artery disease and 99% left anterior descending stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and was given dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia and was given atropine, followed by PEA arrest and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). She was successfully resuscitated and was placed on ECMO and a tandem heart. However, the tandem heart was removed due to a shunt, and ECMO was discontinued.

The patient is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema due to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential. She has known Klebsiella pneumonia and is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient is also experiencing distributive shock, likely secondary to sepsis, and has increasing leukocytosis. She has a central line infection and has been switched to a new antibiotic regimen.

She has pancreatitis, with a lipase level of 220, and is experiencing abdominal pain. She has a normal triglyceride level, and an abdominal ultrasound shows no evidence of duct dilation or cholecystitis.

The patient has acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.5, and is making urine at a rate of 40cc per hour. She is being treated with vasopressin and phenylephrine for cardiogenic shock, and her cardiogenic shock is likely secondary to stunned myocardium after her PEA arrest.

The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 23.8, and is being transfused with packed red blood cells. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, but has not been in atrial fibrillation recently.

The patient's neurologic status is improving, with increased responsiveness and movement, but she is still unable to move her extremities. She has a history of hyperglycemia, and her blood glucose levels have been elevated over the past several days.

The patient's goals of care are to focus on comfort and quality of life, with a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further decline in respiratory function, potentially leading to ventilator dependence
* Worsening of pancreatitis, potentially leading to pancreatic necrosis or abscess formation
* Development of sepsis or septic shock, potentially leading to multi-organ failure
* Progression of acute kidney injury to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease
* Development of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, potentially leading to pulmonary hypertension or respiratory failure
* Further decline in cardiac function, potentially leading to cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation, potentially leading to sepsis or death
* Development of central nervous system complications, such as meningitis or encephalitis, potentially leading to brain death or vegetative state.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and optimize her quality of life.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope, chest pain, and cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and was intubated for respiratory distress. She developed septic shock, pancreatitis, acute kidney injury, and cardiogenic shock after a PEA arrest. She is currently receiving vasopressin and phenylephrine for hemodynamic support and is on TPN for nutrition.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be secondary to pulmonary edema, hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, or ARDS. She requires ongoing oxygen therapy and may require a tracheostomy.
2. Distributive shock: The patient's septic physiology may be secondary to pneumonia, pancreatitis, or cholecystitis. She requires ongoing antibiotic therapy and may require a thoracentesis to evaluate for empyema.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may be complicated by pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, or pseudocyst formation. She requires ongoing pain management and may require a peg tube for nutrition.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.5, and she may be at risk for MODS. She requires ongoing fluid management and may require continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
5. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may be secondary to stunned myocardium or LV thrombus. She requires ongoing vasopressor therapy and may require PCI or CABG.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be secondary to ongoing bleeding, bone marrow failure, or hemolysis. She requires ongoing transfusion support and may require further evaluation of her reticulocyte count.
7. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is improving, but she remains unable to move her extremities. She may require further evaluation with an MRI or LP.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may be secondary to her underlying condition or medication. She requires ongoing glucose monitoring and may require insulin therapy.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's ongoing care requires close monitoring of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurologic status. She requires ongoing antibiotic therapy, vasopressor therapy, and nutritional support. She may require further evaluation with imaging studies or invasive procedures. Her family should be involved in the decision-making process regarding her care, including the potential for tracheostomy, thoracentesis, and CRRT.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope episode and chest pain, cardiac cath showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent PCI and was intubated for respiratory distress. She developed cardiogenic shock, sepsis, pancreatitis, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 280 mL, respiratory rate of 16, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. She has a high oxygen requirement, and her SpO2 is 97%. She has been off sedation all night and failed three pressure support trials.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's cardiac output is decent, but she has low systemic vascular resistance (SVR), likely due to sepsis. She has been weaned off pressors and is no longer in cardiogenic shock.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL, which is stable from yesterday. She has been making good urine output with lasix gtt overnight.
* Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis with increasing lipase levels and is receiving fentanyl boluses for comfort.
* Neurologic: The patient is now very responsive and participatory, moving toes and arms well, and trying to speak. Her CT head shows no evidence of stroke.
* Nutrition: The patient is NPO (nothing by mouth) for pancreatitis and is receiving TPN.
* Other: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which has been treated with amiodarone, and has been weaned off pressors. She has been diagnosed with sepsis, pancreatitis, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen requirement is high, and she may develop respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a history of cardiogenic shock, which can recur if not managed properly.
* Neurologic complications: The patient has a history of cardiogenic shock, which can lead to neurologic complications such as stroke and seizures.

The patient's goals of care are DNR (do not resuscitate), and her disposition is ICU care.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She has a history of cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and has been on mechanical ventilation for 13 days. She has been diagnosed with acute kidney injury, pancreatitis, and sepsis, and has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors. She has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and has been treated with anti-arrhythmic medications.

The patient's current condition is stable, with her blood pressure and oxygen saturation within normal limits. She is still intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and her respiratory status is being closely monitored. She is also receiving treatment for her pancreatitis, including antibiotics and pancreatic enzymes.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is improving, but she may still be at risk for further complications, such as organ dysfunction or failure.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is ongoing, and she may require continued treatment with antibiotics and pancreatic enzymes.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is stable, but she may still require continued treatment with diuretics and monitoring of her kidney function.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is stable, but she may still require continued treatment with anti-arrhythmic medications to prevent further complications.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is ongoing, and she may require continued treatment with insulin to control her blood sugar levels.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is being closely monitored, and she may require continued treatment with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to ensure adequate nutrition.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but she still requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain, with a diagnosis of 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. The patient has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and has been intubated for respiratory distress.

The patient has developed several medical complications, including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient has been experiencing tachypnea and has failed a pressure support trial. The differential diagnosis includes pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Distributive shock: The patient has been weaned off pressors and is currently on antibiotics. The ID consultant has recommended meropenem, cipro, and vancomycin.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has been in atrial fibrillation for the past two nights and may require restarting amiodarone.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase levels are elevated, and she is receiving fentanyl boluses for pain control. The GI consultant has recommended holding statin therapy.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and she may be in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
6. Cardiogenic shock: The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest but has since recovered.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, but the etiology is unclear.
8. Neurologic status: The patient is now responsive and participatory, but the etiology of her altered mental status is unclear.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient has been experiencing hyperglycemia, which may be related to the study protocol.

The patient's current medications include:

* Phenylephrine
* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Heparin sodium
* Metoprolol
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Fentanyl
* Meropenem
* Cipro
* Vancomycin

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.1°C (96.9°F)
* Heart rate: 92 bpm
* Blood pressure: 100/49 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's laboratory results include:

* WBC: 17.2 K/uL
* Hct: 25.8%
* Platelet count: 312 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL
* Lipase: 417 IU/L
* Amylase: 26 IU/L
* Troponin-T: 19.34 ng/mL
* ALT: 80 IU/L
* AST: 92 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 162 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies include:

* CT head: No evidence of stroke
* CT torso: No evidence of intraabdominal bleed

The patient's current goals of care are to continue aggressive diuresis, wean vent settings as tolerated, and manage her medical complications. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and her disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain, which was found to be related to 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, and was intubated for respiratory distress. She developed bradycardia and was given atropine, which converted to PEA to VT arrest. She received a tandemheart in the cath lab, but it was retracted to partially in the RA, causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated, and later removed. She was weaned off pressors and improved mentally. A tracheostomy was placed, and she is currently on ventilator support.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including hypoxemic respiratory failure, distributive shock, atrial fibrillation, pancreatitis, acute kidney injury, cardiogenic shock, anemia, and hyperglycemia. She has been diagnosed with Klebsiella pneumonia, and is receiving antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to pulmonary edema, acute congestive heart failure, hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, or ARDS. She is at risk for further respiratory decline if not managed properly.
2. Distributive shock: The patient's distributive shock is likely secondary to sepsis or cardiac dysfunction. She is at risk for further hemodynamic instability if not managed properly.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely secondary to her underlying cardiac condition. She is at risk for further cardiac complications if not managed properly.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is likely secondary to her underlying medical condition. She is at risk for further pancreatic damage if not managed properly.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely secondary to her underlying medical condition. She is at risk for further kidney damage if not managed properly.
6. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely secondary to her underlying cardiac condition. She is at risk for further cardiac complications if not managed properly.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to her underlying medical condition. She is at risk for further anemia if not managed properly.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely secondary to her underlying medical condition. She is at risk for further hyperglycemia if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's distributive shock with antibiotics and hemodynamic support.
3. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with antiarrhythmic medications.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with supportive care and nutrition.
5. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with diuresis and renally dosed medications.
6. Continue to manage the patient's cardiogenic shock with hemodynamic support and cardiac medications.
7. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with transfusions as needed.
8. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin therapy.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Nutrition: TPN
2. Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale, insulin in TPN
3. Lines: Arterial line, multi-lumen line, 20-gauge line
4. Prophylaxis: DVT (systemic anticoagulation: heparin gtt), stress ulcer (H2 blocker), VAP (HOB elevation, mouth care)
5. Communication: Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate), disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was treated with POBA LAD and LCx with VT, and subsequently intubated for respiratory distress. She developed bradycardia, PEA to VT arrest, and required CPR.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on ventilator support with a tidal volume of 280 mL, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%. She has a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute and is agitated.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 100/49 mmHg. She has atrial fibrillation and is on amiodarone.
* Neurological status: The patient is now very responsive and participatory, moving her toes and arms well, and turning her head and trying to speak.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine is elevated to 2, and she is experiencing acute kidney injury. She is receiving lasix gtt and metolazone to manage her fluid status.
* Hematological status: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and she is receiving antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has pancreatitis, and her lipase is elevated. She is receiving fentanyl boluses for pain control.
* Nutritional status: The patient is NPO for pancreatitis and is receiving TPN.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she may develop further respiratory distress.
* Distributive shock: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and she may develop further episodes of distributive shock.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may persist, and she may require further treatment to manage her heart rate.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and she may require further treatment to manage her renal function.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, and she may require further treatment to manage her abdominal pain.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may recur, and she may require further treatment to manage her cardiac function.

The patient's goals of care are to be DNR (do not resuscitate) and to receive ICU care. The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 76-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope episode, chest pain, and cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, intubation for respiratory distress, and dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia, atropine was given, and PEA to VT arrest occurred. CPR was performed for 2 minutes, and she received 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, and 100mg of lidocaine. ECMO was initiated, but removed due to partial retraction of the tandem heart, causing a shunt. She was weaned off pressors and currently on antibiotics.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: likely secondary to pulmonary edema, acute congestive heart failure, hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, or ARDS.
2. Distributive shock: weaned off pressors, currently on antibiotics, with ID consultation.
3. Atrial fibrillation: has been in atrial fibrillation for the past two nights, with a need to restart amiodarone.
4. Pancreatitis: lipase elevated, with abdominal ultrasound showing no evidence of stones.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: creatinine elevated to 2, stable from yesterday, elevated from 1.0 on admission.
6. Cardiogenic shock, s/p STEMI: relatively resolved after stunned myocardium had a chance to recover.
7. Anemia: unclear etiology, but will transfuse as needed.
8. Neurologic status: patient is now very responsive and participatory, with a CT head showing no evidence of stroke.
9. Hyperglycemia: no history of DM, presented hyperglycemic, with a need for ISS.

The patient's current medication regimen includes:

* Meropenem
* Cipro
* Vancomycin
* Heparin
* Furosemide
* Phenylephrine
* Famotidine
* Fentanyl
* Acetazolamide
* Metoprolol
* Hydrocortisone (study protocol stopped)

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: may require intubation or non-invasive ventilation.
2. Sepsis: may occur due to ongoing infection or pancreatitis.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: may worsen if not managed aggressively.
4. Cardiac complications: may occur due to cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, or cardiomyopathy.
5. Neurologic complications: may occur due to anemia, hyperglycemia, or pancreatitis.
6. Pancreatitis: may worsen if not managed aggressively.
7. Infection: may occur due to ongoing infection or pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the plan of care should focus on:

1. Aggressive management of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis management.
3. Acute Kidney Injury management.
4. Cardiac management, including consideration of PCI or CABG.
5. Neurologic management, including consideration of ISS.
6. Pancreatitis management.
7. Infection management.

The patient's code status is full code, and her family has been notified.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope, chest pain, and cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She had a cardiac catheterization with POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, intubated for respiratory distress, and received dopamine for hemodynamic support.

Current status:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilator support with a tidal volume of 280 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 23 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 22 cmH2O. She has a respiratory rate of 21 inspirations per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 258 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 88 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 106/57 mmHg. She has a central venous pressure of 12 mmHg and a pulmonary artery pressure of 25/10 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a urine output of 3,800 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Neurological: The patient is currently responsive and participatory, moving her toes and arms well, and turning her head and trying to speak.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has pancreatitis with elevated lipase levels and is receiving fentanyl for pain control.
* Infectious disease: The patient is on antibiotics, including meropenem, cipro, and vancomycin, and has a white blood cell count of 16.4 x 10^9/L.

Potential medical complications:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is high, and she may require more aggressive respiratory support.
* Distributive shock: The patient's blood pressure is low, and she may require further treatment for distributive shock.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient has been in atrial fibrillation for the past two nights and may require restarting amiodarone.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase levels are elevated, and she may require further treatment for pancreatitis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may require further treatment for acute kidney injury.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient had cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and may require further treatment for cardiogenic shock.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she may require further treatment for anemia.
* Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is improving, but she may require further monitoring and treatment.

Assessment and plan:

* Continue respiratory support with a trial of pressure support again today.
* Wean vent settings and diuresis today.
* Trial with 40mg IV lasix tomorrow.
* Continue meropenem, cipro, and vancomycin.
* Follow up culture results and trend WBC and T.
* Follow up beta-glucan and galactomannan.
* Restart amiodarone for atrial fibrillation.
* Consider holding statin for pancreatitis.
* Continue TPN and restart tube feeds if GI agrees.
* Monitor anemia and transfuse as needed.
* Continue to follow neurological status and monitor for any changes.
* Follow up with ENT for epistaxis and oropharynx bleeding.
* Monitor hyperglycemia and adjust treatment as needed.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia and was given atropine, but eventually went into VT arrest and received CPR. She was placed on ECMO and tandem heart, but these were later removed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxemic respiratory failure likely secondary to pulmonary edema due to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
* Cardiovascular status: Weaned off pressors and doing better, but still requiring antibiotics and close monitoring.
* Neurological status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory, with no evidence of stroke on CT head.
* Renal status: Patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 2, stable from yesterday.
* Pancreatitis: Lipase is elevated, and patient is receiving fentanyl for pain control.
* Hyperglycemia: Patient has no history of diabetes but presented hyperglycemic and remains hyperglycemic.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Patient may experience further respiratory distress and failure, which could lead to worsening of her condition.
* Cardiac complications: Patient may experience further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, or ventricular tachycardia, which could worsen her condition.
* Renal failure: Patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further complications.
* Pancreatitis: Patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further complications.
* Hyperglycemia: Patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Maintaining tidal volumes at ARDS net goals
* Weaning vent settings as tolerated
* Trial of pressure support again
* F/u cultures
* Continuing antibiotics
* Continuing aggressive diuresis
* Trach stitches can be removed
* Continuing abx
* Vanc trough
* Follow-up culture results
* Trend WBC, T
* Continuing meropenem, cipro, vanc
* Follow-up beta-glucan and galactomannan
* Considering restarting amiodarone
* Repleting lytes prn
* NPO except meds
* Appreciating GI recs
* Considering holding statin
* Continuing lasix gtt and increasing metolazone dose
* Renally dosing medications and checking vancomycin trough
* Continuing heparin gtt for potential LV thrombus
* PCI vs CABG when stable
* Continuing metoprolol as BPs can tolerate

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 minutes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of
   ECMO and tandem heart. Weaned pressors. Improved mental status. Trach
   placed.
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.  Failed pressure
   support trial today due to tachypnea. Diuresed well yesterday and able
   to wean vent settings.
   - trial of pressure support again today.
   - PO diuresis today - 80mg lasix, 5mg metolazone
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Distributive shock: Weaned off pressors and doing better. Currnetly
   on antibiotcs. ID consulted. On meropenem, cipro and vanc. Consider
   micafungin in future.  White count decreasing.
   - continue meropenum, cipro ([**3-10**])
   - check vanco level
   - trend WBC, T
   - follow up beta-glucan and galactomannan
   #. Cardiogenic shock , s/p STEMI: The patient was in cardiogenic shock
   after PEA arrest. S/p removal of ECMO and tendemheart. Now relatively
   resolved after stunned myocardium had chance to recover s/p STEMI.
   - Echo showed improved MVR
   - possible PCI tomorrow - need to discuss pre-hydration therapy
   - Continue metoprolol as BPs can tolerate
   #. Atrial fibrillation: [**Month (only) 8**] need to restart amiodarone if occurs in
   future.
   - follow telemetry, not on amiodarone currently.
   #. Pancreatitis: Lipase elevated. Getting fentanyl boluses for pain
   control. TG normal. Abdominal ultrasound shows no evidence of stones.
   GI consulted.
   - appreciate GI recs
   - restart tube feeds if GI agrees
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine elevated to 2, stable from
   yesterday, elevated from 1.0 on admission.  Made good urine w lasix gtt
   overnight.  Pressors have been weaned off, but restarted yesterday
   during episode of atrial fibrillation.
   - may need to give back some fluid with bicarb prior to potential
   Tuesday catherization.
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem
   heart has been removed.  unclear etiology, but will transfuse as
   needed.  Hct stable for now
   -  Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   -  TPN today vs TF for today
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding
   - ENT will follow if needed
   - Appears resolved.
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains
   hyperglycemic however over past several days.
   - ISS
   # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow
   for passy-muir valve.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain, followed by cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent POBA LAD and LCx with VT and was intubated for respiratory distress. She developed bradycardia, PEA arrest, and required CPR. A tandemheart was inserted, but had to be removed due to a shunt. ECMO was initiated, and pressors were weaned off. The patient's mental status improved, and a tracheostomy was placed.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema and acute congestive heart failure.
2. Distributive shock, which has been weaned off pressors, but antibiotics and ID consultation are ongoing.
3. Cardiogenic shock, which has resolved after removal of ECMO and tandemheart, and stunned myocardium has had a chance to recover.
4. Atrial fibrillation, which is being monitored, but not currently treated with amiodarone.
5. Pancreatitis, with elevated lipase levels, but no evidence of stones on abdominal ultrasound.
6. Acute kidney injury, with elevated creatinine levels, but stable urine output after lasix gtt.
7. Anemia, with unclear etiology, but transfusions as needed.
8. Neurologic status, which has improved significantly, with increased responsiveness and movement.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and intubation increase the risk of pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's distributive shock and ongoing antibiotics suggest a high risk of sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and cardiogenic shock increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated lipase levels and ongoing abdominal symptoms suggest a high risk of pancreatitis complications.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and ongoing fluid management increase the risk of acute kidney injury complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia and unclear etiology increase the risk of bleeding complications.
7. Neurologic deterioration: The patient's improved neurologic status is encouraging, but ongoing monitoring is necessary to detect any potential deterioration.

Recommendations:

1. Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue antibiotics and ID consultation for distributive shock.
3. Consider PCI for the patient's cardiogenic shock, if indicated.
4. Monitor the patient's pancreatitis and abdominal symptoms closely.
5. Continue managing the patient's acute kidney injury and anemia.
6. Continue monitoring the patient's neurologic status and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider adjusting the patient's anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombosis and embolism.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia and PEA arrest, requiring CPR and ECMO. She was weaned off pressors and is currently on antibiotics. She has several comorbidities, including cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, pancreatitis, acute kidney injury, anemia, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to pulmonary edema due to acute congestive heart failure, but other causes such as hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS should be considered.
2. Distributive shock: The patient's distributive shock may be related to sepsis, and the ID team is consulting.
3. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely related to the STEMI and may require PCI.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require treatment with amiodarone.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may require further treatment, including tube feeds and pain management.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may require further management, including fluid management and potentially dialysis.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require transfusion.
8. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is improving, but she may require further monitoring.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may require further management, including insulin therapy.
10. ICU-acquired complications: The patient is at risk for ICU-acquired complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, central line-associated bloodstream infection, and pressure ulcers.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue antibiotics and ID consultation for sepsis.
3. Consider PCI for cardiogenic shock.
4. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and consider treatment with amiodarone.
5. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis, including tube feeds and pain management.
6. Monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and adjust fluid management as needed.
7. Consider transfusion for anemia.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust treatment as needed.
9. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia, including insulin therapy.
10. Monitor the patient for ICU-acquired complications and adjust treatment as needed.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. To PCI soon
   #. Coronary Artery Disease: the patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic
   shock after PEA arrest.
   - PCI today or tomorrow
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - heparin gtt
   - continue low dose beta blocker if pressures can tolerate
   - NPO p MN for cath tomorrow
   - mucomyst
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.  Failed pressure
   support trial today due to tachypnea. Diuresed well yesterday and able
   to wean vent settings.
   - continue pressure support to condition lungs
   - PO diuresis today - 80mg lasix
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Infectious disease: Currently requiring phenylephrine. ID consulted.
   Discontinued antibiotics yesterday per ID recs. Will follow closely.
   - trend WBC, T
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan
   - culture if spikes
   - consider restarting antibiotics if spikes
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent. Again had
   episode last PM. Was given IV lopressor and converted to sinus rhythm.
   [**Month (only) 8**] need to restart amiodarone if occurs in future.
   - cont telemetry
   - cont beta blocker
   #. Pancreatitis: Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved.
   Getting fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal
   ultrasound shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.
   - appreciate GI recs
   - restarted tube feeds
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.3, trending down
   from peak of 2. Still elevated from 1.0 on admission. Making good urine
   to PO lasix.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - cont PO lasix
   - mucomyst prior and post cath
   - pre and post cath hydration protocol
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem
   heart has been removed.  unclear etiology, but will transfuse as
   needed.  Hct stable for now.
   -  Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   -  NPO for possible procedure - will resume TF when okay
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding has resolved
   - ENT will follow if needed
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains
   hyperglycemic however over past several days.
   - ISS
    # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient Summary:**

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and acute kidney injury. She was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent a cardiac catheterization and was found to have 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed hypothermia, bradycardia, and PEA arrest, and was treated with a tandemheart and ECMO. She has since been weaned off pressors and is now only on phenylephrine.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Coronary Artery Disease:** The patient's coronary artery disease is a significant risk factor for further cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. **Atrial Fibrillation:** The patient's recurrent and intermittent atrial fibrillation is a concern, as it can increase the risk of stroke, heart failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.
3. **Acute Kidney Injury:** The patient's acute kidney injury is a concern, as it can increase the risk of further kidney damage, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiovascular complications.
4. **Pulmonary Edema:** The patient's pulmonary edema is a concern, as it can increase the risk of respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and mortality.
5. **Infectious Disease:** The patient's history of sepsis and her current requirement for phenylephrine suggest that she may be at risk for further infectious complications, including septic shock and organ failure.
6. **Pancreatitis:** The patient's elevated lipase levels and abdominal pain suggest that she may be at risk for pancreatitis, which can increase the risk of further complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular complications.
7. **Neurologic Complications:** The patient's altered mental status and recent PEA arrest suggest that she may be at risk for further neurologic complications, including stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
8. **Glycemic Control:** The patient's history of hyperglycemia and her current requirement for insulin suggest that she may be at risk for further glycemic complications, including hypoglycemia and hyperglycemic crisis.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including her rhythm, blood pressure, and cardiac enzymes.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function, including her creatinine levels and urine output.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, including her oxygen saturation and respiratory rate.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infectious disease status, including her white blood cell count and blood cultures.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status, including her mental status and neurologic exam.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's glycemic control, including her blood glucose levels and insulin requirements.
7. Consider restarting antibiotics if the patient's white blood cell count increases or if she develops a fever.
8. Consider restarting amiodarone if the patient's atrial fibrillation recurs.
9. Consider transfusing blood products if the patient's hemoglobin level falls below 10 g/dL.
10. Consider adjusting the patient's medication regimen to improve her glycemic control and reduce the risk of further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room (OSH) after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% left main coronary artery disease and 99% left anterior descending artery stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs:
	+ Temperature: 100.3°F (37.9°C)
	+ Heart rate: 119 bpm
	+ Blood pressure: 95/55 mmHg
	+ Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
	+ Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring:
	+ Central venous pressure (CVP): not mentioned
	+ Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): not mentioned
	+ Cardiac index: not mentioned
* Fluid balance:
	+ Total fluid input: 1,745 mL
	+ Total fluid output: 2,200 mL
	+ Urine output: 2,200 mL
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 13.7 x 10^9/L, Hct 28.1%, platelet count 453 x 10^9/L
	+ Electrolytes: Na 141 mmol/L, K 3.9 mmol/L, Cl 97 mmol/L, Ca 8.6 mg/dL, Mg 2.4 mg/dL, PO4 3.6 mg/dL
	+ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): not mentioned
	+ Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
	+ Glucose: 158 mg/dL
* Imaging studies:
	+ Chest X-ray (CXR): shows diffuse bilateral pulmonary opacifications consistent with worsening pulmonary edema
	+ Computed tomography (CT) torso: no evidence of intraabdominal bleed

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, which is higher than normal, and her oxygen saturation is 100%. This suggests that she may be experiencing respiratory failure, which can be secondary to pulmonary edema, hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac catheterization and has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease. She may be at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Infections: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and she has a history of antibiotic use. She may be at risk for infections such as pneumonia, sepsis, or catheter-related bloodstream infections.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of syncope and has been intubated for respiratory distress. She may be at risk for neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, or encephalopathy.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's lipase level was elevated, and she has a history of pancreatitis. She may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
6. Renal complications: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she has a history of acute kidney injury. She may be at risk for renal complications such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or end-stage renal disease.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care should be considered:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and provide hemodynamic support as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and provide electrolyte supplementation as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and provide diuretic therapy as needed.
5. Consider restarting antibiotics if the patient's WBC count remains elevated or if she develops a fever.
6. Consider restarting amiodarone if the patient's atrial fibrillation persists.
7. Consider restarting tube feeds if the patient's nutritional status improves.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and provide neurological support as needed.
9. Consider restarting pancreatitis treatment if the patient's lipase level remains elevated.
10. Consider restarting hyperglycemia treatment if the patient's glucose level remains elevated.

   Lymph:3.0 %, Mono:5.0 %, Eos:1.0 %, Fibrinogen:782 mg/dL, Lactic
   Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Albumin:2.5 g/dL, LDH:591 IU/L, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:3.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. To PCI soon
   #. Coronary Artery Disease: the patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic
   shock after PEA arrest.  Received mucomyst x5 doses last night.
   - PCI today of LMCA
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - heparin gtt continued
   - continue low dose beta blocker if pressures can tolerate
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.  Failed pressure
   support trial today due to tachypnea.  Pressure support [**9-5**] yesterday,
   able to speak one word answers briefly yesterday w Passy-Muir Valve
   trial then tired out, rested on CMV overnight in preparation for Cath
   today.
   - rest today on CMV after PCI, but continue pressure support trials
   starting tomorrow to condition lungs
   - Hold AM lasix dose for today
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Infectious disease: Currently requiring phenylephrine. ID consulted.
   Meropenem restarted yesterday.  WBC stable.
   - trend WBC, Temp
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan
   - culture if spikes
   - consider Bronch by Thoracics/IP to get BAL and clean old blood out of
   lungs
   - AM cortisol for eval of hypotension and hypokalemia
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had
   another episode early AM. Was given IV lopressorx3 and converted to
   sinus rhythm.  Has gone in and out of Afib multiple times this AM,
   converting back to NSR on her own within a few minutes.
   - cont telemetry
   - increase beta blocker frequency to TID
   #. Pancreatitis: Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved. No
   longer needing fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal
   ultrasound shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.  Some mild
   abdominal tenderness this AM after restarting tube feeds yesterday.
   - appreciate GI recs
   - restarted tube feeds, has been NPO p MN for Cath
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.2, trending down
   from peak of 2. Still elevated from 1.0 on admission. Making good urine
   to PO lasix.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - hold PO lasix today prior to Cath
   - mucomyst prior to Cath
   - pre and post cath hydration protocol
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem
   heart has been removed.  unclear etiology, but will transfuse as
   needed.  Hct stable for now.
   -  Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   -  NPO for Cath today
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding has resolved
   - ENT will follow if needed
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains
   hyperglycemic however over past several days.
   - ISS
    # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow
   for passy-muir valve.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications and potential issues have arisen:

1. Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient has experienced recurrent and intermittent AFib episodes, with the most recent episode occurring early in the morning. The patient was given IV metoprolol and converted to sinus rhythm, but has since gone in and out of AFib multiple times.
2. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, with increased oxygen requirements and failure to tolerate pressure support trials. The patient's lungs are likely secondary to pulmonary edema, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
3. Infectious Disease: The patient's white blood cell count is stable, and cultures, beta glucan, and galactomannan are being followed. The patient's temperature has spiked to 101.3°F, and meropenem and cipro were restarted.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase levels were elevated, but have now resolved. The patient has been restarted on tube feeds, but has been NPO at midnight for catheterization today.
5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is 1.2, trending down from a peak of 2. The patient is making good urine output and will be repleted with lytes as needed.
6. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 8.9 g/dL, and the etiology of anemia is unclear. The patient will be transfused as needed.
7. Neurologic Status: The patient's neurologic status has improved, with increased responsiveness and participation. The patient's CT head shows no evidence of stroke.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have remained elevated, despite being off study medication. The patient's blood glucose levels will be closely monitored.
9. Pressure Support Trial: The patient failed a pressure support trial today, requiring increased oxygen requirements and ventilation support.
10. Tracheostomy: The patient's tracheostomy tube is in place, and the patient is being weaned off pressors.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Coronary Artery Disease: PCI today of LMCA, continuation of plavix, aspirin, and statin, and heparin gtt.
2. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: Rest today on CMV after PCI, with pressure support trials starting tomorrow to condition lungs.
3. Infectious Disease: Trend WBC, temperature, and follow-up cultures, beta glucan, and galactomannan.
4. Pancreatitis: Appreciate GI recs, restart tube feeds, and monitor abdominal tenderness.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: Replete lytes PRN, hold PO lasix today prior to cath, and pre and post cath hydration protocol.
6. Anemia: Cont to monitor and transfuse as needed.
7. Neurologic Status: Continue to follow clinical exam and monitor for any changes.
8. Nutrition: NPO for cath today, with restart of tube feeds after catheterization.
9. Epistaxis: Follow-up with ENT if needed.
10. Hyperglycemia: Monitor blood glucose levels closely and consider ISS.

s creatinine is now at 1.2, trending down

Summary:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, is a post-cardiac arrest patient who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and was intubated due to respiratory distress. She has been experiencing atrial fibrillation, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. She has also had episodes of epistaxis and oropharynx bleeding, which have resolved. Her laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, lipase, and troponin-T. She has been receiving various medications, including heparin, phenylephrine, and metoprolol.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's recurrent and intermittent atrial fibrillation may lead to complications such as stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
2. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest, respiratory failure, and multi-organ failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress, leading to chronic kidney disease, dialysis dependence, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Pancreatitis: Although the patient's lipase levels have decreased, she may still be at risk for pancreatitis-related complications, such as infection, bleeding, and multi-organ failure.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged hospitalization may increase her risk of developing infections, such as sepsis, pneumonia, and bloodstream infections.
6. Bleeding: The patient's recent episodes of epistaxis and oropharynx bleeding may indicate a bleeding diathesis, which may worsen with continued anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and prolonged hypotension may have caused neurological damage, which may lead to long-term cognitive and motor deficits.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent pancreatitis and prolonged hospitalization may increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and consider restarting amiodarone if necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure with pressure support ventilation and consider non-invasive ventilation if possible.
3. Monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with supportive care and consider antibiotics if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's infection risk and consider prophylactic antibiotics if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider adjusting anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider ordering imaging studies to evaluate for potential neurological damage.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider ordering imaging studies to evaluate for potential gastrointestinal complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent a cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LMCA disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed hypothermia, which was treated with a hypothermia protocol. She also experienced a PEA arrest, which was treated with atropine and ECMO. She has since been weaned off pressors and is currently on phenylephrine.

The patient has several ongoing medical conditions, including:

* Coronary artery disease: She is status post PCI of LMCA and is currently on an intra-aortic balloon pump.
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: She is likely experiencing pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although other causes such as hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also possible.
* Infectious disease: She is currently receiving meropenem and has a stable WBC count. She is also being monitored for sepsis.
* Atrial fibrillation: She has had recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation and has been converted to sinus rhythm with IV lopressor.
* Pancreatitis: Her lipase levels were elevated, but have since resolved. She is no longer receiving fentanyl boluses for pain control.
* Acute kidney injury: Her creatinine level is currently at 1.2, trending down from a peak of 2.0.
* Anemia: Her Hct level is stable, but unclear etiology.
* Neurologic status: She is now very responsive and participatory, with a stable CT head scan.

Potential medical complications:

* Continued hypoxemic respiratory failure, which could lead to further respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Infectious disease, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
* Atrial fibrillation, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* Pancreatitis, which could lead to further abdominal pain and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Acute kidney injury, which could lead to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Anemia, which could lead to further blood loss and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Neurologic status, which could lead to further decline in mental status and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and vasopressors as needed.
* Consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan of the chest, to rule out other potential causes of respiratory failure.
* Consider further treatment options, such as antibiotics and antifungals, to treat potential infectious diseases.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further treatment options, such as anticoagulation therapy, to prevent further cardiac complications.
* Consider further treatment options, such as nutritional support and pain management, to address potential complications related to pancreatitis and anemia.
* Consider further treatment options, such as dialysis, to address potential complications related to acute kidney injury.
* Consider further treatment options, such as speech and swallow therapy, to address potential complications related to neurologic status.

   Lymph:3.0 %, Mono:5.0 %, Eos:1.0 %, Fibrinogen:782 mg/dL, Lactic
   Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Albumin:2.5 g/dL, LDH:591 IU/L, Ca++:7.3 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. To PCI soon
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA. On Intra-aortic balloon pump s/p PCI.
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - heparin gtt continued
   - wean IABP; place on 1:2 this AM and remove after Bronch
   - continue low dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure
   support
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.  Pressure support 15/6 this morning after having received
   fluids in Cath.  Wedge pressure during Cath yesterday was elevated into
   30s -- pt needs diuresis.
   - restart lasix drip after bolus ; goal -2L for today
   - giving one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic
   alkalosis
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis:
   pH trending upwards on blood gases overnight.  Need to be careful of
   further contraction alkalosis with diuresing further with lasix in the
   setting of metabolic alkalosis.   Consider RTA type 4 which could also
   account for possible potassium wasting.  AM cortisol  yesterday was
   within normal limits.
   - one dose acetazolamide
   #. Infectious disease:
   Currently requiring phenylephrine. ID has been following.  Patient
   appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full course
   antibiotics.  Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be
   infectious.  AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Switched
   to ceftriaxone yesterday.   Temperatures in 99s over last 24 hours.
   - trend WBC, Temp
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan, low suspicion
   - culture if spikes
   - Bronch by Thoracics/IP to get BAL and clean old blood out of lungs
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   #. Pancreatitis:
   Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved. No longer needing
   fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal ultrasound
   shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.  Exam is benign.
   - restarted tube feeds last night; holding for bronchoscopy
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.1, trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.  Hypokalemia does not just
   appear to be associated with diuresis; consider potassium loss through
   kidneys.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   starting up to 48 hours later
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem heart, which
   appeared associated with anemia, has been removed.  unclear etiology,
   but will transfuse as needed.  Old blood suctioned out of trach tube
   persistently but not as much as before, no active bleed.  Hct stable
   for now.
   -          Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - restart tube feeds again slowly after Bronch today
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx
 no acute bleeding, has old clots
   - Thoracics to do Bronch
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
   - ISS
    # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow
   for passy-muir valve.
